organization.fullName: Hospital Universitari Vall d'Hebron Research Institute

identificationModule.briefTitle: Stroke Process in FEmoral Versus Radial Access
identificationModule.officialTitle: Stroke Process in FEmoral Versus Radial Access

leadSponsor.name: Hospital Universitari Vall d'Hebron Research Institute

descriptionModule.briefSummary: In patients with suspected acute stroke due to large vessel occlusion with indication for endovascular treatment, radial access is just as safe, fast, and effective as femoral access, and it improves the entire stroke treatment process.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Investigators will compare the procedure times, angiographic results as well as the clinical evolution and the patient's experience during their hospital stay and after discharge, depending on the arterial access practiced for mechanical thrombectomy.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: Randomized, prospective clinical trial, under conditions of routine, open-label clinical practice, with the main objective evaluated by an independent investigator who was not blinded to the treatment received. The study will be single-center.

armGroups.label: Radial access
armGroups.description: The ischemic stroke treatment will be performed through the radial artery (as first option)

armGroups.label: Femoral access
armGroups.description: The ischemic stroke treatment will be performed through the femoral artery (as first option)

interventions.name: thrombectomy
interventions.description: Extraction of intracranial thrombus in an acute large vessel occlusion

primaryOutcomes.measure: No inferiority of radial access in the recanalization rate
primaryOutcomes.description: To demonstrate the non-inferiority of radial access with respect to femoral access in the recanalization rate (% mTICI 2b-3 in 3 or fewer passes) obtained in patients with large vessel occlusion treated by mechanical thrombectomy.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: No differences in complications in vascular access
secondaryOutcomes.description: Comparison in frequency of access vessel occlusion, bleeding or presence of pseudoaneurysm

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Grades of modified Thrombolysis in Cerebral Infarction
secondaryOutcomes.description: Grade of recanalization after first pass, third pass and at the end of the procedure
Rate of need to change from radial to femoral access and from femoral to radial access

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Degree of disability/dependence after a stroke
secondaryOutcomes.description: modified rankin scale (from 0 to 6, being 0 best and 6 worst)
Beginning of sitting, ambulation, rehabilitation and total time of hospital admission, need for urinary catheter
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At 24 hours and during first 5 days

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Patients with high suspicion of ischemic stroke due to large cerebral vessel occlusion defined by NIHSS\> 10.
* Immediate availability of the entire team responsible for endovascular treatment (Neurologist, Neurointerventional physician, Anesthetist, Nursing, Technicians ...)
* Radial artery diameter â‰¥2.5 mm
* Presence of femoral pulse or patency by ultrasonography in its defect.
* Previous functional independence (mRS 0-2).

Exclusion Criteria:

* Life expectancy of less than 6 months.
* Intracranial hemorrhage
* Patients with pre-existing neurological or psychiatric pathology that may confuse future evaluations.
* No availability for follow-up after 90 days.

ipdSharingStatementModule.description: After finishing the study we will share all the data if a collaboration is proposed
ipdSharingStatementModule.accessCriteria: We will share the data for collaborate with other institutions.
